title: How many speeding tickets do you have? - Quora

response.answer_text: Technically, 0. Well I got one when I was younger but it got bumped down when I challenged it. I’ve been pulled over 4 times in my 12 years of driving, all in New York / New Jersey. I live in Colorado now and have learned that the cops are much less likely to pull over an Audi than they are a Subaru. My car I used in New York, for all 4 times I’ve been pulled over, is a 2004 Acura RSX Type S. Bright blue. Pitch black windows. Somewhat noisy. Got pulled over by an unmarked car on the first date with a girl I would then date for 11+ years. It was embarrassing and they potentially illegally searched my car. I wrote about it here.Got pulled over on the highway for doing approx. 86 mph in a 55. In my (half) defense, the cop set his speed trap right at a point in the highway where the speed limit dipped from 65 to 55. He bumped it down a few mph on the ticket so as to not get me on reckless driving. I was pretty upset because there were many other cars going much quicker than me, but perhaps that’s why I was pulled over. I was easier to catch. Anyway I plead not guilty and got it knocked down to something like rolling through a stop sign. 1 or 2 points on my license instead of many many more. Definitely got lucky here.I supposedly ran a yellow light in jersey (NY plates get you in trouble when you go really south) and was in the intersection when it went red, so I got pulled over. The officer asked me what I was doing down so far in Jersey and I explained that I had a hockey game. He laughed and asked me which rink, what division, and who I was playing that night. He then said I was playing against his brother and that I should kick his ass, and he let me go.I passed a really evil speed trap coming out of jersey and into NY. Around a blind corner, in the rain, there was an officer backed into some trees and bushes with all his lights off. I’m not gonna pretend to know the law but I’ll speak about what I thought the law was, and if it’s true it’s true if it’s not it’s not, but I believed it at the time. If an officer is setting a speed trap like that, their lights must be on. That is what I thought, so I thought this was a pretty malicious speed trap…more like hunting than doing any protecting. So I flash my headlights at a car coming the opposite way to warn him. Shortly after that, flashing lights and I’m pulled over. The officer asked me what I was flashing my lights for and I mentioned how concerned I was about a lot of downed branches from the storm we had just gotten, so I was warning the other driver! He ran my information and came back and said he’ll buy the story for now but that it’s illegal in NY and NJ to flash your lights to warn about speed traps. I don’t know how true that is either, but he let me go (and if he wanted to be a jerk he could have gotten me for the window tints).All in all I’ve been very lucky with my police interactions.

Well, luckily for me, speeding tickets that are on a person’s record expire after a certain amount of time. If it weren’t for that, I’d have quite a few. Shortly after moving to the state of Washington recently, I was pulled over for driving 65 in a 55 mph zone. I had just driven off one of the ferries plying Puget Sound, and was heading home, a trip of about an hour and a half. Seeing the lights behind me was bad enough. Things were about to get worse. He asked for my driver’s license, registration, and proof of insurance. I immediately gave him my license, and started looking for my proof of insurance and registration. Yikes! I couldn’t find my registration or my insurance certificate. I did find the wallet card of my insurer, and offered him that. I told the officer that I was a little disorganized because I had recently bought the car from my brother-in-law, and had just moved to Washington state. The officer said, “Well, welcome to Washington.” Some people might have taken that as a snarky remark, as in “Welcome to our strict Washington traffic laws.” But I took it completely at face value, and said, “Well, thank you!” As I was replying, the officer cracked a little smile, as if enjoying the irony of welcoming me to the state at the same time as stopping me for speeding. He asked me if I was a commuter from my new hometown. Aghast, I said, “Do people really commute that far?” He said, “Oh, yeah, lots of people do.” I said “I can imagine it would be pretty irritating having so many drivers tearing through your town just trying to catch the ferry or head home for the evening.” No response from the officer. The officer went back to his patrol car for a bit, and I said I would keep looking for the registration. After a few minutes, the officer approached the car again. I still had not found the registration, and was thinking I was in for a whopping fine. The officer said, “Don’t worry about finding the registration right now. I’m just going to give you a warning.” Whoa! I guess the two of us had a moment there. Thanks Officer! So, at the moment, I have no speeding tickets on my record.
